orfdb

BigProt Module

Submodules

Constants

This module contains constants used in the ORF finding process. These include default values for minimum and maximum codon length, start and stop codons, and other parameters related to the ORF finding and annotation process.

Database Utilities

This module provides utilities for interacting with the database.

orfdb.bigprot.db_utils.filter_transcript_dict(transcripts_by_id)[source]

Filters out transcripts with empty chrom_starts or block_sizes. So far this only seems to occur with PAR-located genes on chrY, which are problematic for other reasons as well.

Parameters:

transcripts_by_id (dict) – A dictionary of transcripts.

Returns:

A filtered dictionary of transcripts.

Return type:

dict

orfdb.bigprot.db_utils.describe_table(db_connection, table_name)[source]

Describes a table in the database. Uses an empty query to get the column mames (since postgreSQL doesn’t support “DESCRIBE”).

Parameters:

  • db_connection – The database connection.

  • table_name (str) – The name of the table.

Returns:

A list of column names in the table.

Return type:

list

Find ORFs

This script is used to find Open Reading Frames (ORFs) in a set of sequences. It takes as input a FASTA file containing genomic sequences, and a settings.ini file containing the credentials to access the veliaDB. The script also allows for customization of codon settings, including start and stop codons, and minimum and maximum codon length. Advanced settings such as the glob pattern for files containing phylocsf bigwig tracks for 3 frames on both strands, and the number of simultaneous processes to run can also be specified. The output is logged in a specified output path.

orfdb.bigprot.find_orfs.setup_logger(log_fpath, verbosity=20)[source]

Set up the logger.

Parameters:

  • log_fpath (str) – The path to the log file.

  • verbosity (int, optional) – The level of logging. Defaults to logging.INFO.

Return type:

None

argparse.Namespace

orfdb.bigprot.find_orfs.bump_version(version)[source]

Bumps the patch version by 1 for a semantic version string (e.g., v0.9.3 -> v0.9.4).

Parameters:

version (str) – The version string to bump (e.g., ‘v0.9.3’).

Returns:

The bumped version string.

Return type:

str

orfdb.bigprot.find_orfs.perform_analysis(output, dataset_name, genome_fasta_fpath, db_settings_fpath, skip_annotation, min_codon_length, max_codon_length, transcript_chunk_size, max_chunks, num_processes, verbose, accession_namespace, phase_style='gencode')[source]

Conducts the analysis by loading and processing the specified datasets. This includes identifying and optionally annotating Open Reading Frames (ORFs), handling genomic sequences, and analyzing SNP associations along with PhyloCSF bigwig tracks for evolutionary conservation insights.

Parameters:

  • output (str) – The directory path where output files will be saved.

  • dataset_name (str) – The name identifying the dataset being analyzed.

  • genome_fasta_fpath (str) – The file path to the FASTA file containing genomic sequences.

  • db_settings_fpath (str) – The file path to the database settings file (settings.ini) with configuration details.

  • min_codon_length (int) – The minimum codon length for identifying ORFs.

  • max_codon_length (int) – The maximum codon length for identifying ORFs.

  • transcript_chunk_size (int) – The size of chunks into which transcripts are divided for processing.

  • max_chunks (int) – The maximum number of transcript chunks to process, useful for debugging or limited runs.

  • num_processes (int) – The number of processes to run concurrently during the analysis.

  • verbose (bool) – If true, enables verbose logging for more detailed execution logs.

  • skip_annotation (bool) – If true, skips the annotation of ORFs, focusing only on their identification.

  • phase_style (str) – The phase style to be used for CDSs, indicating the coding sequence phase convention (‘gencode’ or ‘ensembl’).

  • accession_namespace (str) – The namespace for the accession numbers of the genome sequences.

Return type:

None

orfdb.bigprot.find_orfs.main()[source]

Main function to parse command line arguments, and initiate the analysis.

Return type:

None

Sequence Tools

This module provides tools for sequence analysis and manipulation. It includes functions for computing GC content, nucleotide probabilities, codon counts and frequencies, extracting sequence blocks, and more.

orfdb.bigprot.sequence_tools.extract_seq_blocks(parent_seq, chrom_starts, block_sizes, source_coordinate_system='gff')[source]

Extract sequence blocks from a parent sequence given start positions and block sizes. Assumes gff-style intervals (1-based, fully-closed).

Parameters:

  • parent_seq (str) – The parent sequence to extract the blocks from.

  • chrom_starts (list[int]) – The start positions of the blocks.

  • block_sizes (list[int]) – The sizes of the blocks.

  • source_coordinate_system (str) – The coordinate system of the start positions and block sizes.

Returns:

A list of strings representing the extracted sequence blocks.

Return type:

list[str]

Extract a sequence from a parent sequence given start positions, block sizes, and strand.

Parameters:

  • block_sizes (list[int]) – The sizes of the blocks.

  • source_coordinate_system (str) – The coordinate system of the start positions and block sizes.

  • strand (str) – The strand (‘+’ or ‘-‘).

  • seq_record_id (str, optional) – The sequence record ID.

Returns:

The extracted sequence.

orfdb.bigprot.sequence_tools.extract_orf_start_context(orf_object, parent_transcript_seq, upstream_length, downstream_length)[source]

Extract the start context of an ORF, which is the potential Kozak sequence starting 4 bp upstream and ending 1 bp downstream of the start codon.

Parameters:

  • orf_object (orf_classes.OrfBase) – The ORF object containing ORF information such as start position and nucleotide length.

  • parent_transcript_seq (Bio.SeqIO.SeqRecord) – The parent transcript sequence from which the ORF start context will be extracted.

  • upstream_length (int)

  • downstream_length (int)

Returns:

A tuple of strings representing the upstream and downstream sequences of the ORF start context.

Return type:

tuple[str, str]

ORF Calling

This module provides classes and functions for finding and annotating Open Reading Frames (ORFs) in a given sequence. It includes classes for representing ORFs and sets of ORFs, and functions for finding ORFs in sequences and sequence sets.

orfdb.bigprot.orf_calling.find_orfs_in_seq_strand(seq, strand, min_codon_length=15, max_codon_length=1000, start_codons=('ATG', 'CTG', 'TTG', 'GTG'), stop_codons=('TAA', 'TAG', 'TGA'))[source]

Find ORFs in a sequence on a given strand.

Parameters:

  • seq (SeqRecord) – Sequence to search for ORFs.

  • strand (str) – Strand to search for ORFs.

  • min_codon_length (int) – Minimum length of an ORF in codons.

  • max_codon_length (int) – Maximum length of an ORF in codons.

  • start_codons (Collection[str]) – List of start codons.

  • stop_codons (Collection[str]) – List of stop codons.

Return type:

Set[OrfBase]

Returns:

Set of ORFs found in the sequence on the given strand.

orfdb.bigprot.orf_calling.find_orfs_in_seq_set(seq_strand_iterable, min_codon_length=15, max_codon_length=1000, start_codons=None, stop_codons=None)[source]

Find ORFs in a set of sequences.

Parameters:

  • seq_strand_iterable (Iterable[Tuple[SeqRecord, str]]) – Iterable of tuples, each containing a sequence and a strand.

  • min_codon_length (int) – Minimum length of an ORF in codons.

  • max_codon_length (int) – Maximum length of an ORF in codons.

  • start_codons (Optional[List[str]]) – List of start codons.

  • stop_codons (Optional[List[str]]) – List of stop codons.

Return type:

Dict[Optional[str], Set[OrfBase]]

Returns:

Dictionary mapping sequence IDs to sets of ORFs found in the sequences.

orfdb.bigprot.orf_calling.find_orfs_in_seq_set_mp(seq_strand_list, min_codon_length=15, max_codon_length=1000, start_codons=None, stop_codons=None, num_processes=0, chunk_size=128)[source]

Finds Open Reading Frames (ORFs) in a collection of sequences using multiprocessing.

Parameters:

  • seq_strand_list (Collection[Tuple[SeqRecord, str]]) – A collection of tuples, each containing a sequence record and a strand.

  • min_codon_length (int) – The minimum length of an ORF in codons.

  • max_codon_length (int) – The maximum length of an ORF in codons.

  • start_codons (Optional[List[str]]) – A list of start codons. If None, defaults are used.

  • stop_codons (Optional[List[str]]) – A list of stop codons. If None, defaults are used.

  • num_processes (int) – The number of processes to use. If 0, uses the number of CPU cores.

  • chunk_size (int) – The size of chunks for dividing the work among processes.

Return type:

Dict[str, Set[OrfBase]]

Returns:

A dictionary mapping sequence IDs to sets of ORFs found in the sequences.

orfdb.bigprot.orf_calling.call_and_annotate_orfs(transcripts_by_id, genome, output_prefix, exons_by_transcript, cdss_by_exon, skip_annotation=False, min_codon_length=15, max_codon_length=1000, start_codons=('ATG', 'CTG', 'TTG', 'GTG'), stop_codons=('TAA', 'TAG', 'TGA'), phase_style='gencode', accession_namespace='genbank', transcript_chunk_size=4096, max_chunks=-1, num_processes=8)[source]

This function identifies and annotates Open Reading Frames (ORFs) within a collection of transcripts, leveraging multiple processes for efficiency. It utilizes genomic sequences, PhyloCSF tracks for evolutionary conservation analysis, and SNP intervals for genetic variation insights. The function supports customization of ORF detection parameters, including codon length and start/stop codons, and allows for optional skipping of the annotation step.

Parameters:

  • transcripts_by_id (Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]) – Maps transcript IDs to their associated metadata.

  • genome (Dict[str, str]) – Associates chromosome names with their corresponding sequences.

  • output_prefix (str) – Specifies the prefix for all generated output files.

  • exons_by_transcript (Dict[str, Dict[int, List[Dict[str, Any]]]]) – Maps transcript IDs to their exons, facilitating detailed ORF annotation.

  • cdss_by_exon (Dict[str, List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – Associates exon IDs with their coding sequences (CDSs), aiding in ORF annotation.

  • skip_annotation (bool, optional) – If True, skips the annotation step to only identify ORFs. Defaults to False.

  • min_codon_length (int) – Sets the minimum codon length for an ORF to be considered valid.

  • max_codon_length (int) – Sets the maximum codon length for an ORF to be considered valid.

  • start_codons (List[str]) – Defines the codons that can act as start codons for ORFs.

  • stop_codons (List[str]) – Defines the codons that can act as stop codons, marking the end of ORFs.

  • phase_style (str) – Determines the phase style to be used in ORF annotation.

  • transcript_chunk_size (int) – Defines the size of transcript chunks for processing, optimizing performance.

  • num_processes (int) – Specifies the number of processes to use for parallel computation.

  • accession_namespace (str) – Defines the namespace for accession numbers in the genome sequences.

  • max_chunks (int)

Return type:

None

ORF Classes

class orfdb.bigprot.orf_classes.OrfBase(parent_sequence_id, start_pos, strand, codons)[source]

Bases: object

Class representing an Open Reading Frame (ORF). The coordinates are pythonic, i.e. 0-based and half-open intervals (the end position is not in the sequence). To convert to GFF/Ensembl coordinates, add 1 to the start position and 2 to the end position.

Initialize an OrfBase instance. :type parent_sequence_id: str :param parent_sequence_id: ID of the parent sequence. :type start_pos: int :param start_pos: Start position of the ORF. :type strand: str :param strand: Strand of the ORF. :type codons: List[str] :param codons: List of codons in the ORF.

Parameters:

  • parent_sequence_id (str)

  • start_pos (int)

  • strand (str)

  • codons (List[str])

FIELDS = ['codon_length', 'nuc_length', 'nuc_sequence', 'parent_sequence_id', 'phase', 'start_codon', 'start_pos', 'end_pos', 'stop_codon', 'strand']
__init__(parent_sequence_id, start_pos, strand, codons)[source]

Initialize an OrfBase instance. :type parent_sequence_id: str :param parent_sequence_id: ID of the parent sequence. :type start_pos: int :param start_pos: Start position of the ORF. :type strand: str :param strand: Strand of the ORF. :type codons: List[str] :param codons: List of codons in the ORF.

Parameters:

  • parent_sequence_id (str)

  • start_pos (int)

  • strand (str)

  • codons (List[str])

property codon_length

Get the length of the ORF in codons. :return: Length of the ORF in codons.

property nuc_length

Get the length of the ORF in nucleotides. :return: Length of the ORF in nucleotides.

property end_pos

Get the end position of the ORF. :return: End position of the ORF.

property nuc_sequence

Get the nucleotide sequence of the ORF. :return: Nucleotide sequence of the ORF.

property aa_sequence

Get the amino acid sequence of the ORF. :return: Amino acid sequence of the ORF.

property unique_id

Get a unique ID for the ORF. :return: Unique ID for the ORF.

property description

Get a description of the ORF. :return: Description of the ORF.

Annotation

This module contains functions for computing and validating Open Reading Frames (ORFs).

It includes functions to compute genomic start of an ORF, exon intervals, chromosomal start positions and block sizes, end phase of each block, ORF value, ORF index, and PhyloCSF statistics for an ORF. It also includes functions to extract and encode numeric vectors, and to populate the VELIA database fields for an ORF.

orfdb.bigprot.annotation.compute_orf_val(assembly_id, start, end, strand, block_sizes, chrom_starts)[source]

Computes the ORF index string.

orfdb.bigprot.annotation.populate_velia_db_fields_orf(orf_object, parent_transcript_dict, orf_id='', velia_id_value=-1, phase_style='gencode', include_table_name=True)[source]

Populates the VELIA database fields for an ORF.

Parameters:

  • orf_object (OrfBase) – The ORF object.

  • parent_transcript_dict (Dict[str, Union[str, int]]) – The parent transcript dictionary.

  • orf_id (str) – The ORF ID. Defaults to an empty string.

  • velia_id_value (int) – The VELIA ID value. Defaults to -1.

  • include_table_name (bool) – Whether to include the table name. Defaults to True.

Returns:

orf_attributes: the populated VELIA database fields for the ORF as a dictionary, exon_indices: A list of integers indicating which of the enumerated exons associated with this parent transcript are overlapped by this ORF orf_cds_phases: A list of integers indicating the phase of each CDS in this ORF, one per exon that was overlapped by the ORF. orf_cds_frames: A list of integers indicating the reading frame of each CDS in this ORF, one per exon that was overlapped by the ORF

Return type:

A tuple containing

orfdb.bigprot.annotation.validate_orf(orf_object, parent_transcript, genome, accession_namespace)[source]

Validate ORF. This function validates the ORF by comparing the internal ORF sequence with the extracted ORF sequence from the genome. :type orf_object: OrfBase :param orf_object: The ORF object to validate. :type parent_transcript: dict :param parent_transcript: The parent transcript of the ORF. :type genome: Dict[str, str] :param genome: The genome from which the ORF is extracted. :type accession_namespace: str :param accession_namespace: The accession namespace for the genome sequences.

Raises:

AssertionError – If the internal ORF sequence does not match the extracted ORF sequence.

Return type:

None

Parameters:

  • orf_object (OrfBase)

  • parent_transcript (dict)

  • genome (Dict[str, str])

  • accession_namespace (str)

orfdb.bigprot.annotation.generate_cds_orf_info(orf_attributes, parent_transcript, exon_indices, cds_phases, cds_frames, exons_by_transcript, cdss_by_exon, cds_orf_linkages)[source]

Generates CDS ORF information for a given ORF.

This function iterates through exon indices, frames, and phases to generate rows of CDS ORF information. It logs warnings for exons with multiple definitions or no associated CDS entries.

Parameters:

  • orf_attributes (Dict[str, Any]) – A dictionary containing attributes of the ORF.

  • parent_transcript (Dict[str, Any]) – A dictionary containing attributes of the parent transcript of the ORF.

  • exon_indices (List[int]) – A list of exon indices relevant to the ORF.

  • cds_phases (List[int]) – A list of phases for each CDS in the ORF.

  • cds_frames (List[int]) – A list of reading frames for each CDS in the ORF.

  • exons_by_transcript (Dict[str, Dict[int, List[Dict[str, Any]]]]) – A dictionary mapping transcript IDs to their exons.

  • cdss_by_exon (Dict[str, List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – A dictionary mapping exon IDs to their CDSs.

  • cds_orf_linkages (Set[Tuple[str, str]])

Return type:

List[Dict[str, Any]]

Returns:

A list of dictionaries, each representing a row of CDS ORF information to be inserted into a database or further processed.

orfdb.bigprot.annotation.annotate_orfs(current_orf_id, transcript_orfs, transcripts_by_id, transcript_seq_strands_by_id, orf_ids_by_idx_str, genome, exons_by_transcript, cdss_by_exon, cds_orf_linkages, kozak_upstream_pssm, kozak_downstream_pssm, phase_style='gencode', accession_namespace='genbank', skip_annotation=False)[source]

This function annotates Open Reading Frames (ORFs) in a single-threaded manner and returns comprehensive ORF-related data. It provides detailed ORF annotations, including basic ORF information, supplemental details, transcript-specific ORF data, and CDS-specific ORF data, alongside an incremented ORF ID.

Parameters:

  • current_orf_id (int) – The identifier for the ORF currently being annotated.

  • transcript_orfs (Dict[str, Set[orf_classes.OrfBase]]) – Maps transcript identifiers to sets of ORF objects.

  • transcripts_by_id (Dict[str, Dict[str, Union[str, int, float]]]) – Maps transcript identifiers to their associated metadata, which may include a mix of strings, integers, and floats.

  • transcript_seq_strands_by_id (Dict[str, Tuple[str, str]]) – Maps transcript identifiers to tuples containing sequence data and strand orientation.

  • genome (Dict[str, str]) – A dictionary containing genome sequences indexed by their identifiers.

  • exons_by_transcript (Dict[str, Dict[int, List[Dict[str, Union[str, int, float]]]]]) – Maps transcript identifiers to their corresponding exons, which are represented as dictionaries of mixed data types.

  • cdss_by_exon (Dict[str, List[Dict[str, Union[str, int, float]]]]) – Maps exon identifiers to their corresponding CDS entries, represented as dictionaries of mixed data types.

  • kozak_upstream_pssm (Bio.motifs.matrix.PositionSpecificScoringMatrix) – A scoring matrix for analyzing the upstream region of the Kozak sequence for translation initiation.

  • kozak_downstream_pssm (Bio.motifs.matrix.PositionSpecificScoringMatrix) – A scoring matrix for analyzing the downstream region of the Kozak sequence for translation initiation.

  • accession_namespace (str) – The accession namespace for the genome sequences.

  • orf_ids_by_idx_str (Dict[str, str])

  • cds_orf_linkages (Set[Tuple[str, str]])

  • skip_annotation (bool)

Returns:

A tuple containing the updated ORF ID and four lists of dictionaries. Each list contains dictionaries with information about ORFs, supplemental ORFs, transcript ORFs, and CDS ORFs, respectively, featuring a mix of strings, integers, and floats.

Return type:

Tuple[int, List[Dict[str, Union[str, int, float]]], List[Dict[str, Union[str, int, float]]], List[Dict[str, Union[str, int, float]]], List[Dict[str, Union[str, int, float]]]]

orfdb.bigprot.annotation.convert_orf_row_to_object(orf_row_dict, parent_transcript, genome)[source]

OrfBase

The ORF object.

BigWig Tracks

This module handles operations related to BigWig tracks. It includes a class BwTracks that encapsulates the functionality for handling BigWig files, including loading the tracks, determining shared chromosomes, and other related operations.

class orfdb.bigprot.bigwig_tracks.BwTracks(bw_file_glob, trackset_name, load_to_ram=False, strand_position=-5, frame_position=-4, make_16bit=False)[source]

Bases: object

A class to handle operations related to BigWig tracks, modified to use shared memory for multiprocessing.

orfdb.bigprot.bigwig_tracks.bigwigger(bw_tracks_a, bw_tracks_b, operator_method_name)[source]

Processes two sets of BigWig tracks to apply a specified operation on shared chromosomes and strand/frames.

Parameters:

  • bw_tracks_a (BwTracks) – The first set of BigWig tracks.

  • bw_tracks_b (BwTracks) – The second set of BigWig tracks.

  • operator_method_name (str) – The name of the operation method to apply (e.g., ‘add’, ‘subtract’).

Returns:

A dictionary with keys as strand/frame tuples and values as dictionaries mapping chromosome names to the result of applying the operation on the chromosome vectors.

Return type:

Dict[Tuple[str, int], Dict[str, np.ndarray]]

orfdb.bigprot.bigwig_tracks.write_non_nan_to_bigwig_vectorized(np_array, bw_file, chrom, start=0, step=1)[source]

Write non-NaN portions of a NumPy array to an open bigWig file in fixedStep format using vectorized operations for improved performance.

Parameters: - np_array: NumPy array containing the values to write. - bw_file: An open bigWig file object from pyBigWig. - chrom: The chromosome name as a string. - start: The start position (0-based) in the genome for the first element in np_array. - step: The step size between elements in np_array, assuming uniform spacing.

Example usage:

bw = pyBigWig.open(“example.bw”, “w”) bw.addHeader([(“chr1”, 249250621)]) # Adjust this header based on your actual data

Example NumPy array with some NaN values: np_array = np.array([0.1, np.nan, 0.2, 0.3, np.nan, np.nan, 0.4])

Write the non-NaN data to the bigWig file, assuming uniform spacing: write_non_nan_to_bigwig_vectorized(np_array, bw, “chr1”, start=100000, step=1000)

bw.close()
